Review: A Monster Calls

By James Bithell

Thomas Cox reviews A Monster Calls, a children's novel that has been making a commotion in the literary world as adults reading to their children realise they're enjoying the novel more than they probably should.

Review: GamePlan

By James Bithell

GamePlan is entertaining, never ceasing to amuse, but the plot lacked complexity and intricacy. Lucie Parker reviews.

Review: Woman in Black

By James Bithell

Celia Scruby reviews the thrilling play Woman in Black.

Review: Fusion La Mer: Turn of the Tides

By James Bithell

An injection of humour and fun gave a new edge to this year's Fusion, but the show lacked the flow and slickness of previous years.

Review: Kiss Me Kate

By James Bithell

Elements of farce, clever humour and sharp choreography made up for a wavering plot line in this hit West End show. Tom Witherow reviews.

Review: 'I Think We Should See Other People' at The Norman Rea Gallery

By James Bithell

The Norman Rea's exhibition "I Think We Should See Other People" gets the once over by Alice Kewellhampton

Review: The Lion King

By James Bithell

Africa's natural beauty and the reverence of Disney's original story is preserved in the Lion King musical. Lucy Maloney reviews.

Review: "A Bigger Splash: Painting After Performance"

By James Bithell

Roisin Astell reviews A Bigger Splash: Painting after Performance, which excitingly brings together the two forms of artistic practice.

Review: God of Carnage

By James Bithell

The Drama Barn's latest offering, God of Carnage, witnesses the unravelling of middle class social etiquette in an argument between two couples. Adam Seldon reviews.

Review: The Ragged Trousered Philanthropists

By James Bithell

A fun pantomime-like atmosphere brought rhythm and camaraderie to the small Studio space. Thomas Cox reviews.

Review: The Innocents

By James Bithell

Laura Simpson is not disappointed or overwhelmed by Francesca Segal's debut novel The Innocents

Review: Pulphead

By James Bithell

Alex Bryan is impressed by the wit and originality of Sullivan's novel Pulphead

Students and the Arts: Central Hall Musical Society

By James Bithell

Poppy Bullard interviews the inspiring Central Hall Musical Society

Review: The Pillowman

By James Bithell

Rosie Brear reviews The Pillowman, one of the most disturbing pieces of theatre on campus.

Review: West Side Story

By James Bithell

The ambition of CHMS's production of West Side Story is commendable, but unfortunately the standard of previous productions have allowed the bar to be set just a little too high. Emily Heggadon reviews.

Review: Yarn Bombing

By James Bithell

Francesca Donovan reviews the wonderful and wonderfully wacky event at York Art Gallery before it temporarily closes for reconstruction.

Review: Peter Pantomime

By James Bithell

A swashbuckling, rip-roaring, sausageingly good show, Paapa Mills-Bampoe wonderfully reviews York Uni's finest entertainment, coining a word or two in the process.

Review: "Black Butterflies: Roma Gypsy Art & Identity"

By James Bithell

Part of the City of York's Holocaust Memorial Week, Black Butterflies gives remarkable insight into the often neglected culture of Travellers. Alice Kewellhampton reviews.

Review: Hedgepig Theatre's 'Miss Julie'

By James Bithell

August Strindberg's 1880 masterpiece about the class struggle is reincarnated into the roaring twenties world of sensuality and scandal, in Andy Curry's touring production of Miss Julie. Jordan Licht reviews.

Review: Cover Up

By James Bithell

Student written play, Cover Up entertained through-out, bringing the Barn audience an unravelling tale of deception and disgrace. Lucie Parker reviews.

Get Your Fix: What's On

By James Bithell

Editor's picks of local art attractions.

Review: The Horologicon

By James Bithell

A book to be savoured and enjoyed, The Horologicon provides you with all the most fabulous and yet useless words you could ever want. Poppy Bullard reviews.

Review: Is It Just Me!

By James Bithell

Awkward and hilarious, award-winning comic has scored a hit with this light and frivolous autobiography.

Review: The Aftermath Exhibition

By James Bithell

A varied and unusual exhibition, 'The Aftermath Exhibition' is well-worth the venture to the top of Micklegate. Carys Brain reviews.

Review: The Making of Landscape

An all-star cast boasting some of the world's greatest Landscape artists, The Making of Landscape leaves you feeling unexpectedly cheated. Roisin Astell reviews.

Review: A Slap in the Face

By James Bithell

Drama Barn's first offering this term is an impressive performance, but leaves much to be desired. Lizzie Stephens reviews.

Video Review: The Settlers

The Norman Rea Gallery reveal their latest exhibition, The Settlers. Poppy Bullard reviews.

Review: Junior Officers' Reading Club - Patrick Hennesy

By James Bithell

The Junior Officer's Reading Club bridges a long unspoken gap between civilian and soldier, giving a transparent, comic, and brutally honest explanation supporting those either side of the divide. Poppy Bullard reviews.

Portrait of a Lady

Paul Emsley's attempt at photorealism in his recent portrait of the Duchess of Cambridge has Aggie Torrance unconvinced.

Review: La Boheme

By James Bithell

The Royal Opera House hosts an opera in four acts which transported the audience to the centre of Parisian romance, with a stunning set and acting to match.
